creator: Mister Jellyfish
title: Transistor Radio Time Machine
materials_required: Old, broken transistor radio (side-dial thumb wheel model preferred)
Sound card that records and plays back audio (dual-sample circuit board)
Two LED tea lights that flicker with an amber glow
Eight inch length of 9-conductor ribbon cable (or equivalent)
Two 3-Volt CR-2035 dime batteries and holder
3/4 inch nylon bushing (or two washers glued together)
Goop or Shoe Goo brand adhesive
description: This project repurposes an old transistor radio into a 'time machine' that plays nostalgic broadcasts through the original speaker. It features custom time destinations and a flickering amber light, resembling old tube radios, with no external signs of modification.
steps: Open the transistor radio case using a flat-head screwdriver.
Remove the circuit board and speaker from the case.
Grind off solder and copper clad from two spots on the radio circuit board near the thumb wheel.
Remove the two switches from the sound board using a soldering iron and solder removing braid, clipping off two leads.
Glue the switches onto the ground-down spots on the radio circuit board using adhesive, ensuring the buttons face the tuning wheel with a small gap. Use tape to hold them in place while drying.
Solder the individual leads of the ribbon cable to the sound board, following the provided color coding.
Remove the wires connected to the speaker and solder the brown and white wires from the sound board to the speaker terminals.

Connect the battery holder by soldering the red wire to the positive terminal and the black wire to the negative terminal, along with the black wire from the sound board. Insulate with electrical tape.

Solder the red wire from the battery holder to one terminal of the potentiometer/switch connected to the thumb wheel, and solder another red wire to the remaining terminal, connecting it to the sound board.
Disassemble the tea lights to remove the LEDs.

Solder the black wire to the flat spot of one LED, then solder the remaining lead to the flat end of the second LED. Solder the remaining lead of the second LED to the red wire coming from the thumb wheel switch. Insulate with electrical tape.
Cut a crescent shape from the nylon bushing, flatten a spot on the tuner thumb wheel, and glue the crescent to the flat spot.
Solder the leads from the sound board to the switches: Blue and Green to Switch #1, Orange and Yellow to Switch #2.
Remove electronic parts from the original radio circuit board to create a flat surface.
Glue the batteries into the holder and glue the circuit board and battery holder to the radio circuit board.
Turn the thumb wheel switch to make the LEDs glow, then glue them in place, aiming for the case slots or transparent dial for a glowing effect.
Reassemble the components in the case, ensuring free movement of the thumb wheels.
Record audio segments onto the sound board by setting the sound board to record, playing audio from a computer speaker, and engaging the switches.
Set the sound board to play. Reassemble the radio. Engage either switch to play back the sounds.
